image.altText: Anne Clifton, a woman with wispy grey hair, stands in front of two large colourful vases.

props.synopsis: This Tasmanian artist's work has been acquired by the prestigious Victoria and Albert Museum in London â€” the significance is yet to be realised, but a local legacy is already taking shape.

title.children: Fire, paint and 'slight anarchy': Artist blown on to the world stage with international acquisition

image.altText: A man sitting in a chair

props.synopsis: Australia's far-right movement has been buoyed by a wave of recent protests against mass immigration, with some saying the rallies were the "biggest thing that's happened in conservative and nationalist politics for a hundred years".

title.children: Far-right figures want to see shift away from Australia's 'legacy' politicians

image.altText: A man gestures as he looks at camera.

props.synopsis: A Tasmanian woman who was allegedly the subject of a dispute that left one man dead and another accused of his murder says she has almost no memory of the evening because she had used "a lot of drugs".

title.children: Witness denies remembering night that left friend dead and housemate accused of murder

image.altText: Combined images of man in electric car, smiling, blue background, parabolic radio antenna.

props.synopsis: Grote Reber helped spark decades of interest in radio astronomy in Tasmania when he decided to call the southern state home.

title.children: Pioneering astronomer behind first 'big dish' led 'thrifty' life and never wasted a pencil

image.altText: A close-up shot of a woman's pregnant belly, with two hands cradling the bump

props.synopsis: A proposal by the Tasmanian government to introduce a public homebirth model has been welcomed by those in the sector.

title.children: Tasmanian women may soon be able to access public homebirths

image.altText: A statue holding a set of scales on a blue background

props.synopsis: Finding out that remains of a loved one ended up part of a museum collection without permission would be nothing short of shocking. An inquest into the actions of UTAS's RA Rodda Pathology Museum has found that's exactly what happened. Airlie Ward talks with reporter Loretta Lohberger.

title.children: TassieCast: How did a museum illegally collect human remains for decades?

image.altText: Slices of body parts covered in Perspex and put on display on walls.

props.synopsis: A Tasmanian coroner has released his findings from an investigation into 177 human specimens held in the collection of a university museum without the consent or knowledge of families.

title.children: Body parts taken without consent for museum display, coroner finds

image.altText: Cut potatoes which show evidence of Mop Top Virus

props.synopsis: Biosecurity Tasmania is working to trace the origins of the two potatoes, as potato mop-top virus continues to spread through Tasmania.

title.children: Mop-top virus found in potatoes bought from Tasmanian retail stores

image.altText: A slow shutter speed blurs the movement of two horses training at a racetrack.

props.synopsis: A Tasmanian racing integrity investigation finds a number of racing stewards, including the acting chief thoroughbred steward, placed more than 200 bets on races across a two-and-a-half-year period.

title.children: Stewards placed hundreds of bets on Tasmanian races, investigation finds

image.altText: A composite image ofÂ Benjamin Netanyahu and Vladimir Putin.

props.synopsis: In the Middle East and in Europe, political leaders are making their own arrangements in the absence of US leadership.

title.children: Putin's drones and Netanyahu's strikes show a geopolitical shift is underway

image.altText: A blurred out image of a woman looking into a mirror.

props.synopsis: Dr Stan Theodoros is facing disciplinary proceedings, lodged by Queensland's health ombudsman, in the Queensland Civil and Administrative Tribunal (QCAT).

title.children: Brisbane doctor accused of performing 'sexually motivated' checks

image.altText: A white tent with "American Comeback Tour" written on it is seen behind police tape and a uniformed officer.

props.synopsis: Young Australians say they are seeing graphic video of US commentator Charlie Kirk being shot dead pop up in their social media algorithms without warning.

title.children: Young Australians watched Charlie Kirk's assassination without warning

image.altText: One man runs and another cycles away from a huge cloud of smoke and dust where a building has been blown up.

props.synopsis: Israel has dramatically ramped up its attacks in Gaza City in the past week with a targeted campaign to strike its high-rises. Hundreds of structures have been destroyed, forcing thousands of already displaced Palestinians to flee.

title.children: Israel's air strike campaign levelling Gaza City's remaining buildings

image.altText: A Virgin and Qantas plane flying in opposite directions with two velocity and frequent flyer credit cards in the foreground.

props.synopsis: Millions of Australians are signed up to airline loyalty schemes, but a new global ranking finds travellers are getting poorer value than from overseas carriers.

title.children: Hidden risks of frequent flyer points and one traveller's $5,000 lesson

image.altText: Three people smile for a selfie in front of the burning Singha Durbar building

props.synopsis: A calm has fallen on Nepal's streets after days of violence and chaos. But leaders of the gen Z protest movement say the work's not done.

title.children: Why Nepal's gen Z protesters say they 'have not yet won the war'

image.altText: An elderly lady on sitting on a walker, having a cup of tea on a verandah

props.synopsis: Elderly residents of Porepunkah have had their home nurse visits cancelled as alleged police killer Dezi Freeman remains at large.

title.children: Dezi Freeman manhunt leaves elderly people without in-home care

image.altText: A man in a press conference

props.synopsis: The Office of the Independent Assessor found Mr Thompson breached conduct rules when circulating an email criticising another council worker's delays in responding to his request for legal funding.

title.children: Suspended Townsville mayor found to have breached code of conduct

image.altText: A black and yellow frog and a woolly alpaca in two separate images next to each other.

props.synopsis: Disease-resistant frogs, cane-toad-munching quolls and other gene-edited native animals could be roaming the nation within the next decade. What could go wrong?

title.children: Frogs with alpaca genes could soon be hopping around Australia

image.altText: Ricky stands and looks into the distance, his brown hair long at the back and short at the front.

props.synopsis: Two weeks ago, the Canberra Raiders won the NRL's 2025 minor premiership by beating the Wests Tigers. It is their first minor premiership since 1990, and a lot has changed since then.

title.children: How things have changed since the Canberra Raiders last won a minor premiership

image.altText: A Muslim woman with brown skin stands dressed in a headscarf infront of a shelf holding her hands

props.synopsis: When Nausheen Hashmi moved to a south-west Victorian farming town, she wondered how the locals would greet her and her children. She need not have worried.

title.children: Migrants help fading small country town flourish

image.altText: A composite image with headshots of Anthony Albanese and Donald Trump.

props.synopsis: The MAGA president's grip on the Republican party is near total while Albanese holds a sway over his left-leaning caucus like few of his Labor predecessors.

title.children: Trump and his 'good man' Albanese have more in common than you think

image.altText: A young Dau bounces a baskteball on an outside court

props.synopsis: Last weekend, Dau Akueng, 15, and Chol Achiek, 12, were fatally stabbed on their way home from basketball in Melbourne's western suburbs. The pair are being remembered by those who knew them for who they were, not just for how they tragically died.Â

title.children: Two boys killed in Melbourne's west remembered for ambition and kindness

image.altText: Gout Gout flexes after winning a race.

props.synopsis: The 2025 World Athletics Championships in Tokyo sees Australia's largest-ever team tackle the best athletes on the planet. Here are the key events you won't want to miss.

title.children: When does Gout Gout run and the other key events at the World Championships

image.altText: Giorgio Armani waves as he walks down a runway smiling.

props.synopsis: Giorgio Armani's will has surprised fashion watchers as it contains instructions to gradually sell off his company to a luxury brand or seek a listing on the stock market, in seeming contrast to his fiercely independent stance throughout his career.

title.children: Armani's will surprises with instructions to sell brand or list on stock market

image.altText: American golfer John Daly looks down the fairway, following his ball after a tee-shot.

props.synopsis: John Daly is known as "Wild Thing" for his big-hitting, swashbuckling play, but the US golfer's round went right off the rails on the PGA Tour Champions, hitting the water seven times on a par-5.Â

title.children: John Daly makes wrong kind of golfing history with 19 on par-5

image.altText: A white man in a dark blue suit jacket, button up shirt, black pants, walking along a public footpath.

props.synopsis: After almost two weeks of evidence, a court hears closing statements in the trial of former Alice Springs school principal Gavin Morris, who is accused of physically assaulting five children.

title.children: Court hears closing remarks in trial of former Alice Springs principal

image.altText: A man wearing a mask carefully excavates sediment.

props.synopsis: It was on a sweltering morning in 2018 in a cave in northern Vietnam when Chris Stimpson and his team uncovered what may be the oldest cold case murder in South-East Asia.Â

title.children: Archaeologists find evidence of homicide dating to ice age

image.altText: Two bowls of baked lentils topped with spiced sweet potatoes, red onion, slivered almonds and feta. A nourishing easy meal

props.synopsis: This jazzy little bowl is made from simple ingredients. The sweet potato is roasted gently with spices and tinned lentils are roasted until crisp.

title.children: Nourishing and easy sweet potato and lentil bowls

image.altText: Royal Children's Hospital Melbourne

props.synopsis: Melbourne's Royal Children's Hospital says a symposium on the effect of war on children has been cancelled due to safety fears, but some doctors say pressure from a group opposing antisemitism is to blame.

title.children: Hospital's children in war event cancelled amid safety fears

image.altText: A close-up of the under side of a shark in the water.

props.synopsis: Scientists say increasing numbers of east coast grey nurse sharks is rare good conservation news for the critically endangered species.

title.children: Population surge for endangered sharks labelled 'labradors of the sea'

image.altText: white car with orange taxi signs

props.synopsis: A New York-style approach to taxi fees will roll out at Sydney Airport in a bid to put an end to fare rip-offs.

title.children: Sydney Airport to cap taxi fares in crackdown on overcharging

image.altText: A composite image showing a birthday message, a Banksy mural and the Mars rover

props.synopsis: See if you can work out who said it, and what they were talking about.

title.children: Can you match what they said to the news? Time to tackle the ABC's Quote Quiz

image.altText: Person smiles slightly with closed mouth. They have short dark hair and stand against a plain background.

props.synopsis: In their latest book, author and human rights lawyer Keio Yoshida draws on their personal experience and legal expertise to demonstrate the importance of sharing queer stories.

title.children: Keio Yoshida's new book fights for more considered recognition of queer lives
